Graphical abstract The CuZnO catalyst with excellent low-temperature catalytic activity is widely used in methanol steam reforming (MSR). Here, a series of CuZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared by a two-step impregnation method using structured γ-Al2O3/Al support. The unique synergistic effect of Cu2O/ZnO on MSR was found by the experimental and numerical investigation. The experimental characterization results show that the decoration of ZnO can regulate the content of Cu+ on the catalytic surface, and the increase of Cu+ shortens the self-activation response time of the catalyst. During the self-activation process, ZnO-encapsulated Cu nanoparticles (Cu NPs) surface induced by strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) was observed. The encapsulation not only inhibited the agglomeration of Cu NPs but also formed a large number of new Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites. Furtherly, the numerical calculation show that the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites significantly reduced the activation energy of methoxy dehydrogenation (the rate-determining step of MSR). Keywords Hydrogen production Methanol steam reforming Copper catalyst Cu/ZnO/Al2O3/Al Synergistic site 1 Introduction Hydrogen is considered to be one of the most promising energy carriers for the transition to renewable energy [1,2]. Compared with gaseous hydrogen storage, the in-situ conversion of liquid fuel to produce hydrogen can effectively solve the storage and transportation difficulties and reduce the risk of flammability and explosion [3]. Due to the relatively mild reaction conditions, methanol steam reforming (MSR) has been considered a cost-effective way to obtain hydrogen energy [4]. Moreover, it has intrinsic merits in providing high-purity hydrogen free of carbon monoxide for fuel cells of small mobile devices [5–7]. Cu-based catalysts are widely used in the study of steam reforming (SR) because of its high selectivity and low-temperature activity [6,8–10]. Although the research on Cu-based catalysts has a long time, there are still challenges in recognition of its active components. Traditionally, Cu0 is believed to be the main active component in SR [11]. However, with the advancement of in-situ characterization techniques, the understanding of Cu+ dynamically present in the SR is gradually increasing [12–15]. Recently, Gong et al. [14] reported that the ratio of Cu+/Cu0 significantly affected the catalytic activity of dimethyl ether steam reforming (DME SR). In our previous work, we found that Cu+ can initiate the in-situ self-activation behavior of Cu/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst in DME SR [16]. Nevertheless, there is still a lack of targeted studies on the role of Cu+ in SR. Therefore, extensive experimental evidence is needed to understand the valence state conversion mechanism of copper and clarify the correlation between Cu species of different valence states and MSR catalytic performance. As it is known that Cu is easy to sinter at high temperature [17]. Reducing the particle size of Cu not only improves the atomic utilization but effectively prevents the sintering of Cu particles [18,19]. Generally, the confinement effect of supports such as Al2O3, CeO2, etc. with a large specific surface area can inhibit the agglomeration of Cu particles [20,21]. More generally, using an effective method to prepare the catalyst and adding structural stabilizing additives, such as ZnO, ZrO2, etc. is also one of the main methods to improve the stability of Cu particles [22–24]. ZnO is one of the common additives to improve the activity and stability of copper-based catalysts [8,25,26]. However, the synergistic effect between Cu and ZnO is still unclear. Early on, ZnO was thought to be able to assist water dissociation, and the oxygen vacancies on its surface affect the reducibility of Cu [27,28]. It was found that new active sites were formed on the surface of Cu particles decorated with ZnOx species in a reducing atmosphere, and these active sites show strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) through electron rearrangement [25,29–31]. Although theoretical studies indicated that there was a strong charge transport effect between ZnO and Cu2O [32], most of the current studies have focused on the interaction between metal Cu0 and ZnO [33,34]. Recently, Yoshinobu et al. [35] reported that the synergistic effect of Cu2O and ZnO in CuZnO catalysts could promote the methoxy dehydrogenation, which is commonly regarded as the rate-determining step of MSR [36,37]. However, it is still unclear about the nature of the active sites and the structure-activity relationship when Cu0, Cu+, and ZnO are simultaneously present in MSR. γ-Al2O3 with high specific surface area and thermal stability is a common catalyst support [25,38]. Moreover, it can be formed by self-growth on self-designed Al-based materials by the anodizing method [20,39]. Compared with coating catalysts that are easy to peel off, the structured mesh-type γ-Al2O3/Al support prepared by this method has more excellent mechanical strength and flexibility [40,41]. Therefore, the preparation of structured Cu-based catalysts using the support can lay the foundation for future industrial applications. In this work, the CuZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst was prepared for the activity and stability evaluation in MSR. A series of CuZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts with different ZnO content were firstly studied by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, and N2O titration to discuss the effect of ZnO on physicochemical and activities of catalyst. Secondly, the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites induced by in-situ self-activation were discovered by HRTEM, XPS, and EPR. Finally, the structure-activity relationship of the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites in MSR was investigated by DFT calculation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation As reported in our previous work, mesoporous γ-Al2O3/Al was prepared by the anodizing method [16]. A series of CuZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared by a two-step impregnation method. Firstly, at 90 ℃, γ-Al2O3/Al was immersed in molten zinc nitrate (99.9 %). By varying the immersion time, ZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al with different ZnO loadings was prepared. Secondly, ZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al was immersed in 2 mol/L copper nitrate solution at room temperature for 12 h. The weight percentage of Cu was set as 10 wt% in the final catalyst. The catalyst precursor after each impregnation was air-dried overnight at room temperature, and then calcined at 500 ℃ for 4 h. The prepared catalysts were named C10Zx-A (x = 0, 0.5, 1.5, 3.0, 4.5), where x is the loading of ZnO. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Brunner-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the catalyst was obtained by nitrogen adsorption on Micromeritics ASAP 2020-M after degassing at -196 ℃ for 6 h. The content of Cu and Zn in the catalyst was measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) on the Agilent 710ES. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation source. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were carried out by the Micromeritics ChemSorb 2720. First, the sample was treated at 500 ℃ for 1 h under flowing Ar gas to desorb any impurities and moisture. After cooling to room temperature, a gas of 10 vol.% H2-N2 was introduced. Finally, the temperature was increased to 600 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃ min−1. Through the stoichiometric N2O titration based on [2Cu + N2O → Cu2O + N2] and H2 reduction methods, the Cu surface area, dispersion degree, and Cu2O reduction temperature of the catalyst were measured on the Micromeritics Chemsorb 2720 equipment. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were collected by FEI NanoSEM 450. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained on a JEM 2100 electron microscope operated at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. To calibrate the effects of charge, the C 1s peak from carbon contamination was set to 284.6 eV. Thermogravimetry (TG) results were recorded in a thermal analysis system (WRT-3P-TGA Instruments). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of the catalyst were measured on a Bruker A300 spectrometer at room temperature. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation MSR was carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed tubular reactor under atmospheric pressure (Figure S1). The mesh-type catalyst (3.0 g) cut into 20 mesh was diluted to the fixed bed height with quartz sand of the same mesh. Based on the previously reported catalyst self-activation behavior, all catalysts had not been subjected to in-situ pre-reduction treatment. The methanol-water solution (n(H2O) : n(CH3OH) = 2:1) was pumped into the evaporator (150 ℃) through an HPLC pump, then mixed with nitrogen (30 mL/min) as a balance gas, and finally entered the tubular reactor. The reactor temperature range was 225 ℃ to 350 ℃, and the GHSV was 4000 mL gcat −1 h-1. Gas products were analyzed by on-line gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The chromatogram was calibrated using pure gases (CO, CO2, DME, N2, H2, and CH4) of known concentrations (although CH4 was not detected in this study). In the stability evaluation, the catalytic bed was firstly heated to 225 °C at a rate of 5 °C min-1, and then the raw materials were directly fed into the MSR reaction for 3 h. This process is called the in-situ self-activation of the catalyst. After that, the temperature was raised to 300 °C at 5 °C min-1 for durability evaluation. In terms of GC analysis, GC sampling and analysis were started 5 min after feeding. After that, the analysis of gaseous products is performed every 15 min. Methanol conversion, Hydrogen yield, and the selectivity of gaseous carbon products were calculated as follows: (1) MeOH conversion (%) = F MeOH,in - F MeOH,out F MeOH,in × 100% (2) H 2 yield (%) = F H 2 ,out 3× F MeOH,in × 100% (3) Ci selectivity (%) = F Ci,out ∑ F Ci,out × 100% F MeOH,in and F MeOH,out are the molar flow rates of methanol at inlet and outlet, respectively. F H2 is the molar flow rate of H2. F Ci,out is the molar flow rate of gaseous carbon products (such as CO2, CO, DME) in the outlet gas. The overall carbon balance was calculated as follows: (4) overall carbon balance = {[moles of CO + moles of CO2 + 2(moles of DME) + moles of MeOH(out)] / (moles of MeOH(in))} × 100 % Overall carbon balance closure of all the experimental results in this work can reach 100 % ± 3%. 2.4 DFT method DFT calculation was carried out by the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [42] with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [43]. The cutoff energy of plane-wave basis set was 450 eV. The surface Brillouin zone was sampled with a (2 × 2 × 1) Monkhorst–Pack k-points grid mesh for all slabs [44]. To avoid interactions between repeated slabs along the z-direction. A vacuum spacing of 15 Å was set in the z-direction between any two repeated slabs to avoid interaction between any two adjacent slabs. The bottom two layers of all slabs were frozen, while the remaining layers were allowed to relax. The reaction pathway and transition states were searched by climbing image nudged elastic band (cNEB) [45] method and further confirmed by vibration frequency analysis. The adsorption energies (E ads) of models are defined by the following equation (5) E ads = E ad/sub - E ad - E sub where E ad/sub, E ad, and E sub are the energy of the optimized adsorption system of adsorbate and substrate, adsorbate in the gas phase, and the clean substrate, respectively. The binding energy (E b) of models is defined as follows (6) E b = E mod/Cu - E mod - E Cu where E mod/Cu, E mod, E Cu are the energy of the copper model containing surface modifier, modifier in the gas phase, and the original three-layer Cu (111) planes, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of ZnO on physicochemical properties and activities of catalyst The textural properties of the sample, as well as the information of Cu dispersion and particle size were summarized in Table 1 . The results show that the addition of ZnO promoted Cu dispersion. However, it is noted that the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased while ZnO loading over 1.5 %, which was due to the destruction of pores caused by long-term immersion in an acidic solution. Fig. 1 a shows the XRD information of the catalysts. No diffraction peaks of ZnO were found in any of the samples, which was due to the high dispersion of ZnO species on the support surface [8]. The intensity of the CuO diffraction peaks decreased significantly with the addition of ZnO, indicating that the addition of an appropriate amount of ZnO can inhibit the growth of Cu particles during the calcination process. However, it was noted that the (11-1) and (111) diffraction peaks of CuO shifted to low angle with the addition of ZnO (Fig. 1b). The XRD Rietveld refinement results (Fig. 1c) show that the unit cell parameter is 4.66 Å, which is slightly larger than the lattice constant of CuO (0.465 nm). This phenomenon was caused by the presence of Cu+ as reported in the literatures (Cu+ radius: 0.6 Å; Cu2+ radius: 0.57 Å) [46,47]. Fig. 2 a shows that the reduction behavior of the calcined Cu/ZnO samples was studied by H2-TPR. The reduction peaks exhibited by the samples between 200 ℃ and 300 ℃ can be attributed to the reduction of copper oxide [16]. All samples showed three distinct reduction peaks (labeled αCu, βCu, and γCu) after deconvolution. The two peaks of βCu and γCu formed at higher temperatures belong to the bulk Cu2+ reduction in steps, which was consistent with law of stepwise reduction of Cu2+ reported in previous studies and the recognition of a high Cu2+ reduction energy barrier [48]. The reduction of the αCu peak occurred at a lower temperature than the other two peaks, and it was speculated that the peak may be caused by more active Cu+ [5]. To verify this hypothesis, the catalyst after N2O oxidation (containing only Cu2O) was used for the H2-TPR for the second time. The second TPR profile (yellow line in Fig. 2b) show that the reduction of Cu2O occurred at about 185℃, which closely matched the αCu peak (210 ℃), confirming that the αCu peak was caused by Cu2O reduction. By comparison, the peak area of the α peak increased significantly with the addition of ZnO, which shows that the amount of Cu2O formed was positively correlated with the ZnO loading during the calcined catalyst. It is worth noting that the Cu+ species with lower oxidation state can be reduced immediately at low temperatures and highly reducing conditions, although it is proved that there is more Cu2O on the catalysts containing ZnO. Therefore, in order to stabilize the valence of Cu2O in the reaction, in addition to constructing the interaction of the bimetallic oxide (Cu2O-ZnO), it is also important to replace hydrogen with a mild reducing agent (such as methanol and water) [19]. To investigate the strengthening of Cu-based catalyst by ZnO in MSR, the catalytic performance was evaluated by the gradient heating experiment. All the catalysts were activated by feeding raw gas at 225℃. Compared with the C10Z0-A catalyst, a higher CH3OH conversion was obtained on all ZnO-containing catalysts in Figure S2a. The CH3OH conversion of C10Z1.5-A was significantly higher than that of other samples, especially in the activity evaluation with the self-activation temperature of 225 ℃, which was in agreement with the data from H2-TPR and N2O titration. However, when the ZnO loading was higher than 1.5 %, the catalytic activity decreased because of the specific surface area of the active component decreasing. Figures S2b-d show that the CO2 selectivity was maintained at 90 %, and CO was generated above 275 ℃. 3.2 Self-activation and high-temperature stability evaluation To evaluate the thermal stability of the catalyst, Fig. 3 d shows the results of self-activation and high-temperature stability evaluation of the samples. The catalyst was self-activated in the feed gas at 225 °C for 3 h and then heated to 300 °C for high-temperature stability evaluation. The morphology and average particle size (defined as D crystallite) of the C10Z1.5-A and C10Z0-A catalyst at the corresponding stage were obtained by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and N2O titration. It can be found that the conversion of C10Z1.5-A after self-activation is 62 %, which is significantly higher than that of C10Z0-A (42 %). In the high-temperature stability evaluation, the conversion of C10Z0-A dropped significantly by 22 % after 35 h. SEM images show that the reason for the decrease in activity is the agglomeration and sintering of Cu NPs (Fig. 3e–g). Fig. 3a–c show that the conversion of C10Z1.5-A was relatively stable after 77 h of high-temperature stability evaluation. Lunkenbein et al. [49] found that controlling ZnO polymorphism was critical to the stability of the catalytic system. Because the effect of ZnO as the most mobile compound in the system is usually underestimated, and the crystallization of the zinc phase can cause the evolution of the Cu/ZnO interface [25,30]. Therefore, this improvement effect may be due to the migration of ZnO to the Cu surface. 3.3 In situ self-activation-induced surface reconstruction To compare the effect of self-activation on the crystal form, two activation treatments were used in the catalyst. The hydrogen pre-reduction treatment is named "hydrogen activation", and the other in-situ reduction in the feed gas is named "self-activation". Fig. 4 a shows that the only Cu diffraction peak in the C10Z0-A sample was found after the two activation treatments. However, for C10Z1.5-A (Fig. 4b), Cu2O diffraction peaks in addition to the Cu peak proves that the Cu2O phase still existed in the ZnO-containing sample after self-activation. This indicated that ZnO may inhibit the full reduction of Cu2+ to Cu°, thereby retaining more Cu+ content. And the coexisting structure of Cu2O/ZnO existed in the whole stage of self-activation. Additionally, compared with the result of activation with hydrogen, the intensity of the Cu diffraction peaks of the C10Z1.5-A after self-activation was reduced, and a diffraction peak of the ZnO (002) plane was identified. Mendes et al. [8] demonstrated that the polar ZnO (002) plane had a significant effect on improving the MSR activity of the copper-based catalyst. It can be speculated that the initially highly dispersed ZnO particles formed the polar ZnO (002) plane on the surface of Cu NPs during self-activation, which reduced the crystallinity of Cu and stabilized the Cu2O species on the catalytic surface. The Cu2O/ZnO interaction was further examined by using H2-TPR. As can be seen from Fig. 5 b, the reduction temperature of Cu after reoxidation of C10Z1.5-A was lower than that of fresh C10Z1.5-A, indicating that CuZn interaction is enhanced during the self-activation. Through the secondary TPR curve after N2O oxidation treatment, it was found that the original temperature of Cu2O was further reduced by 22 ℃. The results prove that the interaction between Cu2O and ZnO is also enhanced. There was no apparent change in the reduction peak position of C10Z0-A in Fig. 5a, which indicates that this phenomenon cannot occur without ZnO. To investigate the state of CuZn catalytic interface, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was used to observe the morphological changes of Cu NPs before and after self-activation. For the fresh catalyst, the CuO (111) plane was clearly observed (Fig. 6 a–b). However, after self-activation treatment, a large number of Cu NPs covered with ZnO shell were observed at the activated C10Z1.5-A surface (Fig. 6c–d). By comparing the lattice fringes, it can be confirmed that the cover layer was mainly composed of polar ZnO (002) plane (0.260 nm). The lattice fringes attributed to the Cu2O phase were not observed, which may be due to its main distribution under the ZnO cover layer. Interestingly, the thickness of the cover layer gradually becomes thinner as the particle size increases. When the particle size is greater than 10 nm, complete encapsulation becomes difficult (Figure S3). It is worth noting that the image shows that most of the Cu NPs were encapsulated, but considering that HRTEM is obtained by 2D projection, it cannot be concluded that the Cu NPs were completely encapsulated. Moreover, combined with XRD results, Cu2O may exist in an amorphous state. Therefore, it is speculated that the Cu-Cu2O-ZnO core-shell structure may be formed at the catalytic interface. Fig. 6e shows that the average particle size of Cu NPs was 5.4 nm, which is in agreement with the data from N2O titration (5.2 nm). In addition, the elemental energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images (Fig. 6f) showed a good dispersion of Cu NPs and ZnO on the support, which confirms the existence of a large number of Cu-ZnO interfaces. Previous reports pointed out that the encapsulation of metal by the carrier layer oxide was a typical feature of the SMSI phenomenon. Moreover, this phenomenon has been extensively studied in reverse water-gas shift reaction (rWGS) [30], methanol synthesis [25], and other reactions [29,50]. However, to our knowledge, this is the first time the phenomenon has been observed during the MSR self-activating reaction condition. The strong interaction formed by the Cu-O-Zn interfaces inhibited the aggregation of Cu NPs, enhanced charge transport, and promoted the generation of new MSR active sites. 3.4 Surface chemical states and charge transport To obtain further insight into Cu2O/ZnO interactions in the catalyst before and after activation, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Fig. 7 a) was used to study the valence state of metal elements in the catalyst. The fresh catalysts were accompanied by the shaking satellite peaks of Cu2+ (940−945 eV), and two contributions were discerned at 932.5 eV and 933.8 eV. The higher BE peak was attributed to Cu2+, and the lower BE peak at ∼932.5 eV indicates the existence of Cu+. The ratio of Cu+/(Cu++Cu2+) in fresh C10Z1.5-A increased, which proves the stabilizing effect of ZnO on Cu+. The satellite peak of Cu+ was observed in the activated catalyst, and the characteristic peak of Cu+ and Cu° species with higher intensity appeared. The BE peak at 934.5 eV was attributed to Cu(OH)2, which may be formed by the combination of Cu+ and a large amount of OH on the support surface (Cu++2OH−→Cu(OH)2) [51]. Because Cu 2p3/2 XPS can not differentiate between Cu+ and Cu°, Auger Cu LMM spectra (Fig. 7b) were used to confirm the existence of Cu°, Cu+, and Cu2+ at BE ∼569 eV. There was no possibility of metallic copper in the fresh catalyst calcined in the air environment, so the BE peak at 568.7 eV was attributed to Cu2+, and the BE peak at 567.9 eV after self-activation was assigned to Cu°. Cu+ species (569.9 eV) always exist on the surface of the catalyst. It is worth noting that the addition of ZnO in the fresh catalyst increased the proportion of Cu+ from 20.9%–32.3% (Table 2 ), which played a key role in accelerating the self-activation. The ratio of Cu+/Cu° on the activated C10Z1.5-A catalytic surface was maintained at about 1, which is in accordance with the results of the optimal ratio found by Li et al. [14,23] The ratio of Cu+/(Cu°+Cu+) on activated C10Z0-A was reduced to 19.9 % ​​due to the lack of ZnO regulation. These results further support that the improvement in the MSR activity is related to the synergistic effect of Cu+ and ZnO, and the increase in activity after reoxidation may be related to the re-optimization of the Cu+/Cu° ratio caused by the ZnO encapsulation of Cu NPs. It was reported that oxygen vacancies (Ov) are considered to be important sites for charge transport in the redox process of Cu [19]. Therefore, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was used to explore the regulatory mechanism of Ov on Cu valence. To eliminate the interference of Cu2+ on the paramagnetic signal and obtain a good signal-to-noise ratio (S/N), Z3.0-A (ZnO loading of 3%) without Cu loading was selected. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the signal at g = 2.003 was attributed to the single electron Ov [52]. Combined with TPR data in Fig. 2a, it is found that the existence of Ov promoted the reduction of CuO. However, ZnO encapsulation may avoid the contact of Cu+ with the reducing atmosphere, thereby inhibiting the possibility of further reduction, and ultimately improving the stability of Cu+ in MSR. In addition, the TG analysis based on the method reported by Dunn et al. [53] was observed in the difference in quality loss due to the existence of Ov (Fig. 8b). On the other hand, the existence of a BE peak corresponding to the Ov species (Ob in Figure S4) around ∼531 eV in the deconvolution results of the O1 s XPS also supported the conclusion that there are more oxygen vacancies in the ZnO-containing samples. In summary, the series of characterization results mentioned in the previous sections can firmly prove that there is a strong interaction between Cu2O and ZnO. To accurately understand the synergistic effect of Cu2O and ZnO on the copper-based surface, the four models were used in the DFT calculation. The selection of the Cu (111) plane and the graphene-like ZnO (002) plane was based on the XRD results in Fig. 4b. The construction of the Cu2O/Cu model was based on the research of Rodriguez et al. [54] 3.5 Numerical investigations on structure-activity relationship of the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites To evaluate the adsorption capacity and stability of ZnO and Cu2O, Fig. 9 a shows the adsorption energy (Eads) of the model for methanol and water and the binding energy (Eb) for the encapsulated species [55]. Among the four models constructed, the Cu2O/ZnO/Cu model with Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites showed the maximum adsorption activity. The E ads of the model for methanol and water were 0.56 eV and 0.79 eV, respectively. This result shows that the existence of the synergistic site can enhance the ability of the catalytic surface to capture methanol and water during self-activation, thereby effectively shortening the self-activation time of the catalyst. The E b of the ZnO/Cu model decorated with ZnO on a clean Cu (111) surface was only 2.88 eV. In contrast, on the Cu-based model decorated with the Cu2O, the addition of ZnO increases the E b of the system from 6.12 eV to 7.42 eV. It can be pointed out that the decoration of ZnO and Cu2O can improve the stability of the catalytic system, and this improvement effect becomes more apparent under the synergetic effect of the two species. Further analysis of work function and local density of states is also consistent with this conclusion (Figure S5−6). The methoxy dehydrogenation to formaldehyde intermediate is generally considered the rate-determining step of MSR [36,37]. Fig. 9b shows the activation energy for methoxy dehydrogenation on the Cu, ZnO/Cu, and Cu2O/ZnO/Cu surfaces. The structure of the transition state was shown in Fig. 9c. On the Cu2O/ZnO/Cu surface, this step not only absorbs the least amount of heat (1.02 eV) but also has the lowest activation energy barrier (1.17 eV). Obviously, the introduction of ZnO shows excellent performance in improving catalytic activity, and the existence of Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites in MSR has a significant effect on MSR reaction. 4 Conclusions A series of CuZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared and applied to MSR. The significant influence of ZnO on the physicochemical properties of copper-based catalysts was analyzed by self-activation and stability evaluation. (1) ZnO with valence state regulation function can maintain the optimal ratio of Cu+/Cu0 to 1 in MSR. In the self-activation, the ZnO encapsulation of Cu NPs not only inhibited the agglomeration of Cu NPs, but also formed a large number of new Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites. (2) The numerical calculation found that the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites had a strong adsorption capacity for methanol and water, thereby shortening the self-activation response time of the catalyst. Moreover, these new active sites have lower work function and higher electron delocalization, which can improve the anti-reduction ability of Cu2O. (3) At the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic site, the activation energy (1.17 eV) of methoxy dehydrogenation (the rate determining step of MSR) is lower than that of Cu/ZnO (1.25 eV) and Cu (1.36 eV), which proves that ZnO and Cu2O have excellent synergistic effect. coredata.dc:description: The CuZnO catalyst with excellent low-temperature catalytic activity is widely used in methanol steam reforming (MSR). Here, a series of CuZnO/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared by a two-step impregnation method using structured γ-Al2O3/Al support. The unique synergistic effect of Cu2O/ZnO on MSR was found by the experimental and numerical investigation. The experimental characterization results show that the decoration of ZnO can regulate the content of Cu+ on the catalytic surface, and the increase of Cu+ shortens the self-activation response time of the catalyst. During the self-activation process, ZnO-encapsulated Cu nanoparticles (Cu NPs) surface induced by strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) was observed. The encapsulation not only inhibited the agglomeration of Cu NPs but also formed a large number of new Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites. Furtherly, the numerical calculation show that the Cu2O/ZnO synergistic sites significantly reduced the activation energy of methoxy dehydrogenation (the rate-determining step of MSR).
coredata.dc:title: In-situ self-assembled Cu2O/ZnO core-shell catalysts synergistically enhance the durability of methanol steam reforming
